questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Figure 1 is a simplified periodic table that gives the atomic number, symbol, name, and electronegativity (EN) of 21 elements. Rows of elements are called periods. Columns of elements are called groups.


Figure 1 adapted from Nivaldo J. Tro, Chemistry: A Molecular Approach, 2nd ed.©2011 by Pearson Education, Inc.


The greater the EN of an element, the more strongly an atom of that element attracts electrons to itself in a chemical bond. The greater the absolute value of the differ­ence between the ENs of 2 elements, | EN1 - EN2 |, the more polar is the bond between atoms of the elements. Figure 2 gives, for each of 6 compounds, | EN1 - EN2 | and the bond energy at 298 K (the energy needed to break all the bonds in 1 mole of a compound at 298 K).


Figure 2 adapted from James G. Speight, Lange's Handbook of Chemistry, 16th ed. ©2005 by McGraw-Hill, Inc.
questions.question: 1. According to Figure 1, the element in Period 2 that is also a member of Group 3A has an EN of:

questions.question: 2. According to Figure 1, all 3 elements in which of the following lists belong to the same period?

questions.question: 3. The atomic number of an element is the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom of that element. According to Figure 1, the nucleus of an atom of which of the following elements contains more protons than does an atom of sulfur?

questions.question: 4. Among the 6 compounds represented in Figure 2, as  increases, the bond energy at 298 K:

choices.D: varies, but with no general trend.

questions.article:
Figure 1 is a simplified periodic table that gives the atomic number, symbol, name, and electronegativity (EN) of 21 elements. Rows of elements are called periods. Columns of elements are called groups.

questions.question: 5. Consider | EN1 - EN2 | in Figure 2 for BeS. Based on Figure 1, is the bond in HBr less polar or more polar than the bond in BeS?

choices.A: Less polar; | EN1 - EN2 | for HBr is less than | EN1 - EN2 | for BeS.
choices.B: Less polar; | EN1 - EN2 | for HBr is greater than | EN1 - EN2 | for BeS.
choices.C: More polar; | EN1 - EN2 | for HBr is less than | EN1 - EN2 | for BeS.
choices.D: More polar; | EN1 - EN2 | for HBr is greater than | EN1 - EN2 | for BeS.

questions.article:

questions.question: 6. Consider a sample composed of molecules of HI. Based on Figure 2, at 298 K, would the amount of energy required to break all the bonds in this sample be greater than 300 kJ or less than 300 kJ ?

choices.A: Greater, because the sample contains more than 1 mole of HI.
choices.B: Greater, because the sample contains less than I mole of HI.
choices.C: Less, because the sample contains more than 1 mole of HI.
choices.D: Less, because the sample contains less than 1 mole of HI.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Triticum aestivum wheat plants grown in a particular soil are affected by salt (NaCl) in the soil, overwatering of the soil, or both. A study examined the effects.

The following 5 steps were performed:

1. Forty identical pots were divided equally into 4 groups (Groups 1—4).

2. Five kilograms (kg) of the soil was put into each Group 1 pot and each Group 3 pot. A mixture of 4.98 kg of the soil and 20 g of NaCl was put into each Group 2 pot and each Group 4 pot.

3. Ten wheat seeds were planted in each pot and watered daily until all the seeds sprouted. Then 7 of the 10 seed­lings were removed from each pot.

4. Over the next 4 months, all the pots received the same amount of sunlight and the same amounts of nutrients daily. Each Group 1 pot and each Group 2 pot received 500 mL of water daily. Each Group 3 pot and each Group 4 pot received 500 mL of water daily, except for 3 consecutive weeks during the third month. Over that 3-week period, each Group 3 pot and each Group 4 pot was overwatered by keeping the water level 1 cm above the top of the soil.

Table 1 describes the differences among the groups.


5. At 4 months, 2 averages were calculated for the plants in each group of pots: the average plant mass (roots included), in g per plant, and the average grain yield (mass of grain produced), in g of grain per plant.

The average plant mass results are shown in Figure 1. and the average grain yield results are shown in Figure 2.



Figures adapted from Muhammad Saqib, Javaid Akhtar, and Riaz Hussain Qureshi, "Pot Study of Wheat Growth in Saline and Water­logged Compacted Soil: [Part] I. Grain Yield and Yield Compo­nents."©2004 by Elsevier B. V.
questions.question:
7. Assume that wheat plants with a greater mass also have a greater height. Based on Figure 1, the average height of the wheat plants in which group of pots was 
greatest?

questions.question: 8. What is the most likely reason that 7 seedlings were removed from each pot in Step 3 ?

choices.A: To prevent the plants from producing grain
choices.B: To avoid overcrowding as the plants grew
choices.C: To reduce the amount of NaCl in the soil
choices.D: To decrease the total mass of the pot’s contents

questions.question: 9. According to Table 1, the Group 1 pots differed from the Group 3 pots with respect to which of the following factors?

choices.A: Mass of soil put into a pot
choices.B: Number of wheat seeds planted in a pot
choices.C: Total amount of nutrients received by a pot
choices.D: Total amount of water received by a pot

questions.question: 10. According to the results of the study, for the Group 3 pots, what was the average plant mass in g/plant, and what was the average grain yield in g of grain/plant?

choices.A: average plant mass: 3.9;      average grain yield: 4.2
choices.B: average plant mass: 3.9;      average grain yield: 7.8
choices.C: average plant mass: 7.8;      average grain yield: 3.9
choices.D: average plant mass: 7.8;      average grain yield: 4.2

questions.article:

questions.question: 11. Based on Figure 2, did NaCl alone or did overwatering alone cause a greater decrease in the average grain yield?

choices.A: NaCl; the average grain yield was less for the Group 2 pots than for the Group 3 pots.
choices.B: NaCl; the average grain yield was less for the Group 3 pots than for the Group 2 pots.
choices.C: Overwatering; the average grain yield was less for the Group 2 pots than for the Group 3 pots.
choices.D: Overwatering; the average grain yield was less for the Group 3 pots than for the Group 2 pots.

questions.question: 12. According to Figure 2, at 4 months, the plants in the Group 4 pots had produced, on average, 2.5 g of grain per plant. To calculate the total mass of grain produced, on average, by the plants in a single Group 4 pot, should 2.5 g be multiplied by 3 or by 10?

choices.A: Three, because at 4 months, there were three Group 4 pots.
choices.B: Three, because at 4 months, there were 3 plants in each Group 4 pot.
choices.C: Ten, because at 4 months, there were ten Group 4 pots.
choices.D: Ten, because at 4 months, there were 10 plants in each Group 4 pot.

questions.article:
Triticum aestivum wheat plants grown in a particular soil are affected by salt (NaCl) in the soil, overwatering of the soil, or both. A study examined the effects.

The following 5 steps were performed:

questions.question: 13. The researchers who performed the study most likely compared the results shown in Figure 1 for the Group 1 pots and the Group 2 pots to answer which of the following questions?

choices.A: What effect did NaCl alone have on average plant mass?
choices.B: What effect did NaCl alone have on average grain yield?
choices.C: What effect did overwatering alone have on average plant mass?
choices.D: What effect did overwatering alone have on average grain yield?

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article:
Both bats and birds have wings used for flight. Two students present opposing views about whether the pres­ence of the wings is an indication that bats and birds are more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings, such as humans. Included in each student's presentation is a cladogram, a diagram that shows the evolutionary history of several species. A clado­gram organizes species into clades based on descent from a common ancestor. A clade is a set of related species and their most recent common ancestor (MRCA).

Student 1
Although both have wings, bats and birds are not more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings. Although the wings of bats and birds evolved in response to similar selective forces, they evolved independently of one another, as shown in Figure 1. The wings of birds evolved at Point A, whereas the wings of bats evolved at Point B.


A bat can move individual wing bones, much like the fingers can be moved in a human hand. The bones in a bird wing are fused and inflexible. Thus, the bone structure of a bat wing is more similar to the bone structure of a human hand than to the bone structure of a bird wing. Furthermore, the fact that both bats and humans share mammalian characteristics provides additional evidence that bats are more closely related to humans than to birds.

Student 2
Their both having wings is a good indication that bats and birds are more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings. The MRCA of all vertebrates with wings must have had wings. As shown in Figure 2, the MRCA of bats and birds, represented at Node Z, evolved to give rise to all winged vertebrates.


Evidence that the bone structure of a bat wing is similar to that of a human hand does not indicate that bats and humans are closely related because bats, birds, and humans all have a similar forelimb bone structure. Humans and bats are both mammals, but the mammalian characteristics of humans and of bats evolved at Points W and X, respectively.
questions.question: 14. Student 2’s cladogram indicates that which of the vertebrates listed below belong to the clade that originates at Node Z?I. HumansII. BatsIII. Birds

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article:

A clado­gram organizes species into clades based on descent from a common ancestor. A clade is a set of related species and their most recent common ancestor (MRCA).

Student 1

The wings of birds evolved at Point A, whereas the wings of bats evolved at Point B.

Humans and bats are both mammals, but the mammalian characteristics of humans and of bats evolved at Points W and X, respectively.
questions.question: 15. Consider the statement “Bats have a small claw that sticks out of the wing and functions like a human thumb, allowing the bat to hang onto and climb on trees.” This statement supports the view of which student?

choices.A: Student 1, because Student 1 claims that any descendant of an ancestor with forelimbs will have a nonfunctional structure that resembles a human thumb.
choices.B: Student 1, because Student 1 claims that the similarity of bone structure between a bat wing and a human hand provides evidence that bats and humans are closely related.
choices.C: Student 2, because Student 2 claims that any descendant of an ancestor with forelimbs will have a nonfunctional structure that resembles a human thumb.
choices.D: Student 2, because Student 2 claims that the similarity of bone structure between a bat wing and a human hand provides evidence that bats and humans are closely related.

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article:
Both bats and birds have wings used for flight. Two students present opposing views about whether the pres­ence of the wings is an indication that bats and birds are more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings, such as humans. Included in each student's presentation is a cladogram, a diagram that shows the evolutionary history of several species. A clado­gram organizes species into clades based on descent from a common ancestor. A clade is a set of related species and their most recent common ancestor (MRCA).

The wings of birds evolved at Point A, whereas the wings of bats evolved at Point B.

Thus, the bone structure of a bat wing is more similar to the bone structure of a human hand than to the bone structure of a bird wing. Student 2

The MRCA of all vertebrates with wings must have had wings. As shown in Figure 2, the MRCA of bats and birds, represented at Node Z, evolved to give rise to all winged vertebrates.

Humans and bats are both mammals, but the mammalian characteristics of humans and of bats evolved at Points W and X, respectively.
questions.question: 16. In Student 1’s cladogram, is the MRCA of bats and humans represented at Node C or at Node D ?

choices.A: Node C, because the clade that begins with the ancestor represented at Node C includes bats and humans, as well as birds, as descendants.
choices.B: Node C, because the clade that begins with the ancestor represented at Node C includes bats and humans, but not birds, as descendants.
choices.C: Node D, because the clade that begins with the ancestor represented at Node D includes bats and humans, as well as birds, as descendants.
choices.D: Node D, because the clade that begins with the ancestor represented at Node D includes bats and humans, but not birds, as descendants.

questions.question: 17. Which of the students, if either, present(s) a cladogram that is consistent with the statement “Birds and humans, but not bats, share a common ancestor that had forelimbs”？

questions.title: Passage Ill
questions.article:
Both bats and birds have wings used for flight. Two students present opposing views about whether the pres­ence of the wings is an indication that bats and birds are more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings, such as humans. Included in each student's presentation is a cladogram, a diagram that shows the evolutionary history of several species. A clado­gram organizes species into clades based on descent from a common ancestor. A clade is a set of related species and their most recent common ancestor (MRCA).

Student 1
Although both have wings, bats and birds are not more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings. Although the wings of bats and birds evolved in response to similar selective forces, they evolved independently of one another, as shown in Figure 1. The wings of birds evolved at Point A, whereas the wings of bats evolved at Point B.


A bat can move individual wing bones, much like the fingers can be moved in a human hand. The bones in a bird wing are fused and inflexible. Thus, the bone structure of a bat wing is more similar to the bone structure of a human hand than to the bone structure of a bird wing. Furthermore, the fact that both bats and humans share mammalian characteristics provides additional evidence that bats are more closely related to humans than to birds.

Student 2
Their both having wings is a good indication that bats and birds are more closely related to each other than either is to other vertebrates without wings. The MRCA of all vertebrates with wings must have had wings. As shown in Figure 2, the MRCA of bats and birds, represented at Node Z, evolved to give rise to all winged vertebrates.


Evidence that the bone structure of a bat wing is similar to that of a human hand does not indicate that bats and humans are closely related because bats, birds, and humans all have a similar forelimb bone structure. Humans and bats are both mammals, but the mammalian characteristics of humans and of bats evolved at Points W and X, respectively.
questions.question: 18. Which of the following cladograms is consistent with the cladogram constructed by Student 2 ?

questions.question: 19. Which of the students, if either, would be likely to claim that the MRCA of bats and birds did not have wings?

questions.question: 20. Student 2 implies that which of the following morphological traits evolved at Points W and X ?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Alcohols are carbon compounds containing a hydroxyl (OH) group. Alkenes are carbon compounds containing at least 1 carbon-carbon double bond (C=C).

Dehydration (removal of H2O) of Alcohol W in the presence of phosphoric acid (H3PO4) produces H2O and a mixture of 4 alkenes (Alkenes 1-4) that each contain only 1 C=C bond:


Dehydration of each of 3 other alcohols (Alcohols X, Y, and Z) produces H2O and 2 or more of Alkenes 1—4. Stu­dents studied the dehydration of each of these 4 alcohols, which are all liquids at 25°C.

Experiment

In each of 4 trials, the students performed Steps 1-5:

1. A 2.30 g sample of Alcohol W, X, Y, or Z was placed in a flask.
2. A 0.5 mL portion of (H3PO4) was added to the flask, and an apparatus for distillation (evaporation of one or more components of a liquid mixture in one vessel and con­densation of the vapors in another vessel) was assem­bled (see Figure 1).


3. The contents of the flask were boiled at 1 atmosphere (atm) of pressure in a heated sand bath. All the compo­nents of the product mixture that distilled before the vapor temperature reached 115 ° C were collected in a test tube that was cooled in ice water.

4. Two mL of saturated salt solution was added to the test tube. The test tube was covered and shaken, and its con­tents were allowed to settle into 2 layers.

5. The percent composition of the top layer (the mixture of alkene products only) was determined (see Table 1).
questions.question: 21. Based on the results of the experiment, the mixture of alkene products resulting from the dehydration of which of the alcohols contained the greatest percent of Alkene 3?

questions.article:

questions.question: 22. Trials 1 and 4 differed with respect to which of the following?

choices.C: The mass of alcohol placed in the flask
choices.D: The volume of (H3PO4) placed in the flask

questions.question: 23. What was the most likely purpose of the sand bath shown in Figure 1?

choices.A: To partially cool the test tube
choices.B: To evenly distribute heat to the flask
choices.C: To provide sand as a reactant in the dehydration reaction
choices.D: To provide sand as a surface onto which the vapors would condense

questions.question: 24. What is the most likely reason that, upon the completion of Step 4, the mixture of alkene products was the top layer in the test tube?

choices.A: The density of the mixture of alkene products was greater than the density of the saturated salt solution.
choices.B: The density of the mixture of alkene products was less than the density of the saturated salt solution.
choices.C: The volume of the mixture of alkene products was greater than the volume of the saturated salt solution.
choices.D: The volume of the mixture of alkene products was less than the volume of the saturated salt solution.

questions.question: 27. One of the students predicted that in Step 3, H2O would be one of the substances collected in the test tube. Based on the boiling point of H2O at 1 atm of pressure and the description of Step 3, was the student’s prediction correct?

choices.A: Yes, because the boiling point of H2O is greater than 115℃.
choices.B: Yes, because the boiling point of H2O is less than 115℃.
choices.C: No, because the boiling point of H2O is greater than 115℃.
choices.D: No, because the boiling point of H2O is less than 115℃.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
The processing of sulfur-rich ore (rock containing valuable metals) from mines produces liquid waste, which is often stored in a pond. Some of the liquid in the pond seeps down to the groundwater table, where it contaminates the groundwater beneath with sulfate (SO42-). A barrier called a reactive wall can be installed in the ground near the pond to lessen SO42- contamination. As polluted water flows through the wall, SO42- is removed from the water (see Figure 1). The material that forms the wall—the reactive material (RM)—is composed of one or more organic substances.


A study evaluated the effectiveness of several reactive materials.

Study
Six reactive materials (RMs 1-6) were prepared from samples of 4 organic substances——sewage sludge, leaf mulch, sheep manure, and sawdust——that had been com­pletely dried. Table 1 show the composition of each RM.


The following procedures were performed for each RM: First, a 500 mL volume of the RM was placed in a 1 L flask. Next, 500 mL of a simulated liquid mine waste with an SO42- concentration of 3,600 mg/L was added to the flask. The flask opening was then covered with an airtight cap. Every 5 days, a 10 mL sample of the liquid in the flask was collected through a seal in the cap. Each sample was analyzed for SO42-. Once a sample was found to have an SO42- concentration of zero, no additional samples were collected from the flask.

Figure 2 shows the results for each RM.


Table and figures adapted from K. R. Waybrant, D. W. Blowes, and C. J. Ptacek, "Selection of Reactive Mixtures for Use in Permeable Reactive Walls for Treatment of Mine Drainage.''©1998 by the American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 28. The movement of liquid waste from a storage pond to the groundwater table is an example of which of the following processes?

questions.question: 29. If a sample of the liquid in the flask containing RM 1 had been collected on Day 22, the SO42- concentration of that sample would most likely have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 31. Consider the reactive materials for which the percent dry mass of leaf mulch was greater than 50%. Did each of those reactive materials remove all the SO42- from the liquid mine waste in their flasks in less than 50 days?

choices.A: Yes, it took only 30 days for RM 2, RM 5, and RM 6 to remove all the SO42- from the waste in their flasks.
choices.B: Yes, it took only 45 days for RM 3, RM 4, and RM 5 to remove all the SO42- from the waste in their flasks.
choices.C: No, it took more than 60 days for RM 2 and RM 5 to remove all the SO42- from the waste in their flasks.
choices.D: No, it took more than 60 days for RM 5 and RM 6 to remove all the SO42-  from the waste in their flasks.

questions.question: 32. Suppose an environmental engineer wants to ensure that a reactive wall as depicted in Figure 1 will remove as much  SO42- from the polluted water as possible. Based on Figure 1, would the engineer more likely achieve this goal by increasing the thickness of the wall or the height of the wall?

choices.A: The thickness, because the polluted water will flow horizontally through the wall.
choices.B: The thickness, because the polluted water will flow vertically through the wall.
choices.C: The height, because the polluted water will flow horizontally through the wall.
choices.D: The height, because the polluted water will flow vertically through the wall.

questions.question: 33. Consider the concentration of SO42- in the liquid mine waste that was added to the flask containing RM 4 on Day 0. Also consider the concentration of SO42- in the sample collected from that flask on Day 25. The concentration on Day 25 was approximately what fraction of the concentration on Day 0?

Some of the liquid in the pond seeps down to the groundwater table, where it contaminates the groundwater beneath with sulfate (SO42-). A barrier called a reactive wall can be installed in the ground near the pond to lessen SO42- contamination. As polluted water flows through the wall, SO42- is removed from the water (see Figure 1). The material that forms the wall—the reactive material (RM)—is composed of one or more organic substances.


A study evaluated the effectiveness of several reactive materials.

Study
Six reactive materials (RMs 1-6) were prepared from samples of 4 organic substances——sewage sludge, leaf mulch, sheep manure, and sawdust——that had been com­pletely dried. Table 1 show the composition of each RM.


The following procedures were performed for each RM: First, a 500 mL volume of the RM was placed in a 1 L flask. Next, 500 mL of a simulated liquid mine waste with an SO42- concentration of 3,600 mg/L was added to the flask. The flask opening was then covered with an airtight cap. Every 5 days, a 10 mL sample of the liquid in the flask was collected through a seal in the cap. Each sample was analyzed for SO42-. Once a sample was found to have an SO42- concentration of zero, no additional samples were collected from the flask.

Figure 2 shows the results for each RM.


Table and figures adapted from K. R. Waybrant, D. W. Blowes, and C. J. Ptacek, "Selection of Reactive Mixtures for Use in Permeable Reactive Walls for Treatment of Mine Drainage.''©1998 by the American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 34. Suppose that a reactive material with a composition of 50 percent by dry mass of the sewage sludge and 50 percent by dry mass of the leaf mulch had been tested in the study. The  SO42- concentration of the sample collected on Day 5 from the flask containing that reactive material would most likely have been:

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Consider an electron that is constrained to move along the x-axis. The probability of finding the electron at any given location, x, along the axis is obtained from a distribu­tion function, DF, which is related to the electron's energy. The greater the value of DF at a given x, the greater the probability of finding the electron at that x. Classical theory and quantum theory can be used to derive 2 forms of DF: a classical form and a quantum form.

Table 1 lists the electron energy corresponding to each of 4 DFs. Figure 1 shows the classical and quantum forms of each DF.
questions.question: 35. The figure below shows the Quantum DF for an electron bound within a hydrogen atom.At approximately what distance from the nucleus is this electron most likely to be found?
